title: U.S. Women Beat Canada to Claim Spot in Paris Olympics
abstract: The Americans’ victory in the final of the Concacaf W Championship avenged a bitter loss to the Canadians at last summer’s Tokyo Olympics.
org_facet: United States Women's National Soccer Team

multimedia.caption: The United States won a record ninth Concacaf women’s title, and its third in a row.

title: Can Batters Hit What They Can’t See? We Will Find Out.
abstract: Dodger Stadium at dusk can be one of the hardest places to hit in baseball. As if Clayton Kershaw and Shane McClanahan, the All-Star starters, needed any help.

multimedia.caption: Clayton Kershaw has started only 12 games this season, but he has been perfect through seven innings twice.
Clayton Kershaw has started only 12 games this season, but he has been perfect through seven innings twice.

title: After Turning Down $440 Million, Juan Soto Just Wants to Play
abstract: Juan Soto is 23 and is already one of the game’s best players. After extension talks broke down, he could be on his way out of town. Until then, he wants to concentrate on baseball.

multimedia.caption: Juan Soto is one of the best hitters in baseball. His agent, Scott Boras, is known for turning production into record-setting contracts.
multimedia.copyright: Gary A. Vasquez/USA Today Sports, via Reuters

title: The Unlikeliest of All-Stars Makes Every Pitch Look Good
abstract: Jose Trevino of the Yankees did not start catching until college, but is so good at manipulating umpires with his pitch framing that he sometimes fools his own pitchers.

multimedia.caption: Jose Trevino is a master of the art of pitch-framing. It has helped him unseat Kyle Higashioka as the Yankees' starting catcher.
Jose Trevino is a master of the art of pitch-framing. It has helped him unseat Kyle Higashioka as the Yankees' starting catcher.
Jose Trevino is a master of the art of pitch-framing. It has helped him unseat Kyle Higashioka as the Yankees' starting catcher.

title: “He is fighting for his first gold medal. I’m trying to defend my territory.”
abstract: Karsten Warholm, the Norwegian reigning world champion and gold medalist in the 400-meter hurdles has a budding rivalry with the American Rai Benjamin. It’s just what track and field needs.

multimedia.caption: A lot of power goes into Karsten Warholm's roar.
A lot of power goes into Karsten Warholm's roar.
A lot of power goes into Karsten Warholm's roar.

abstract: Soufiane El Bakkali of Morocco, the reigning Olympic champion, won the race.

title: Cameron Smith Overtakes Rory McIlroy to Win the 150th British Open
abstract: The Australian turned in a brilliant final round on the Old Course at St. Andrews to finish at 20 under par and capture his first major championship.

multimedia.caption: Cameron Smith of Australia celebrated with the claret jug on Sunday.
Cameron Smith of Australia celebrated with the claret jug on Sunday.

title: Style and Superstar Egos: The Pros and Cons of N.B.A. Coaching
abstract: A weeklong camp helps professional basketball players learn what it takes to become a head coach. “I just know that I can’t play forever,” one attendee said.

multimedia.caption: Justin Anderson, center, is a six-year N.B.A. veteran. He played on a few 10-day contracts during the 2021-22 season and is eyeing coaching as his next career.

title: Meet the New Voice of Baseball
abstract: Joe Davis inherited Vin Scully’s job with the Dodgers. Now, he will replace Joe Buck at the All-Star Game and the World Series. He has done his homework, and he’s ready to shine.

multimedia.copyright: Kyle Grillot for The New York Times

title: At the British Open, Another Letdown for Rory McIlroy
abstract: McIlroy, the 2014 Open winner and a son of Northern Ireland, was a gallery favorite in Scotland. But his streak of major tournament misery will stretch into 2023.

multimedia.caption: Rory McIlroy walking up the 18th fairway during the final round on Sunday.

title: It’s Time to Rescue Mike Trout and Shohei Ohtani
abstract: The Los Angeles Angels have two All-Stars in their prime and a pile of losses to show for it. They might as well make this disastrous season fun to watch, writes our columnist.

multimedia.caption: Aside from their appearance in Tuesday’s All-Star Game, Mike Trout, right, and Shohei Ohtani are stuck in Major League Baseball purgatory.
Aside from their appearance in Tuesday’s All-Star Game, Mike Trout, right, and Shohei Ohtani are stuck in Major League Baseball purgatory.

title: An M.L.B. Draft High on Name Recognition and Star Power
abstract: Jackson Holliday, son of the seven-time All-Star Matt, went No. 1 and Druw Jones, son of Andruw, went No. 2. But Kumar Rocker’s going third was Day 1’s biggest surprise.

multimedia.caption: Jackson Holliday spent his childhood around major league clubhouses thanks to his father, Matt, who was a star outfielder.

title: Hobie Billingsley, Coach of a Diving Dynasty, Dies at 95
abstract: A national champion diver himself, he led Indiana University to glory over 31 years and guided gold medal winners in the Olympics.

multimedia.caption: Hobie Billingsley in 1963, when he was coaching Indiana University’s diving team. “In his coaching, the superscientific Billingsley speaks about linear motion, transitory motion and double-axis displacement,” Sports Ilustrated wrote.

Hobie Billingsley in 1963, when he was coaching Indiana University’s diving team. “In his coaching, the superscientific Billingsley speaks about linear motion, transitory motion and double-axis displacement,” Sports Ilustrated wrote.

abstract: Five golfers who have a good chance to win the tournament, including the defending champion.

title: Around the World, Golf Prodigies Get National Support, but Not in the U.S.
abstract: Country after country helps young men and women pay their way, but those players go it alone in America.

multimedia.caption: Mone Inami, shown at the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games in Kawagoe last summer, said becoming a member of Japan’s national golf team had many benefits, including helping her develop a team sensibility.

title: 21 Under Par? Juli Inkster Did It at the 2003 Evian.
abstract: She reflected on her dominant career, in which she won 31 tournaments and seven majors on the LPGA Tour.

title: Wherever Juan Soto Goes, Remarkable Things Tend to Happen
abstract: After being grilled about turning down a $440 million contract, Soto won the Home Run Derby. All in a day’s work.

multimedia.caption: Juan Soto got through some tough competition in the Home Run Derby on Monday, eliminating Cleveland’s José Ramírez and St. Louis’ Albert Pujols before topping Seattle's Julio Rodríguez in the finals.

title: Quarterback Known as ‘AR-15’ Changes Nickname, Citing Mass Shootings
abstract: Anthony Richardson, a sophomore quarterback and rising star at the University of Florida, asked people to call him “AR” or not use a nickname at all.

multimedia.caption: Florida quarterback Anthony Richardson throwing next to former N.F.L. quarterbacks Eli Manning, center, and Peyton Manning at the Manning Passing Academy on the Nicholls State University campus in Thibodaux, La., in June.

title: Why some of track’s biggest names are not at the world championships
abstract: Many of the sport’s biggest names — Sha’Carri Richardson, Molly Seidel, Eliud Kipchoge and Sam Kendricks — are not competing in Eugene, Ore. this week.

title: Gotytom Gebreslase of Ethiopia wins women’s world championship marathon.
abstract: Judith Korir of Kenya won silver, and Lonah Chemtai Salpeter of Israel won bronze. All three medalists bested the world championship marathon record time set by Paula Radcliffe in 2005.

multimedia.caption: From left, Judith Korir of Kenya, Gotytom Gebreslase of Ethiopia, and Lonah Chemtai Salpeter of Israel. All three medalists bested the previous world championship marathon record set by Paula Radcliffe in 2005.

From left, Judith Korir of Kenya, Gotytom Gebreslase of Ethiopia, and Lonah Chemtai Salpeter of Israel. All three medalists bested the previous world championship marathon record set by Paula Radcliffe in 2005.

title: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Monday.
abstract: Watch the indomitable Faith Kipyegon take on the 1,500 meters in the evening.

title: The 110-meter hurdles was dramatic before it even started
abstract: Hansle Parchment of Jamaica injured himself during a warm up, and Devon Allen was disqualified for a false start.

title: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce leads a Jamaican sweep of the 100-meter race
abstract: It was an expected Jamaican sweep, with Shericka Jackson taking the silver and Elaine Thompson-Herah winning the bronze.

multimedia.caption: Thompson-Herah, Fraser-Pryce and Jackson celebrated their sweep at Hayward Field. The three sprinters also swept the 100-meter podium at the Tokyo Olympics.

title: Yankees Head to the All-Star Break Looking as Dominant as Ever
abstract: A pair of blowout wins over the rival Boston Red Sox helped the Yankees shake off the closest thing they’ve had to a slump all year.

title: Jamaica’s women have taken over sprints. It’s another story for the men.
abstract: Jamaican women have taken over the sprints. Jamaican men, meanwhile, have become an afterthought on the global track and field stage.

title: A Strategic Marathon Ends With a World Championships Record
abstract: Conditions in Eugene were perfect for a fast marathon. Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia won the race in 2 hours 5 minutes and 36 seconds, a record for the world championships.

multimedia.caption: Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia won the marathon in a time of 2 hours 5 minutes 36 seconds.

title: ‘He’s Built for New York’
abstract: Only 21, Anthony Volpe is so talented that the Yankees were willing to let members of the greatest free-agent class of shortstops all land elsewhere.

multimedia.caption: Volpe grew up near the Patriots’ park and was a huge fan of Derek Jeter. He hopes to follow in Jeter’s footsteps.

abstract: Kerley won the gold and was followed by Marvin Bracy-Williams and Trayvon Bromell.

title: Rory McIlroy Has a Big Day at the British Open. Viktor Hovland Follows.
abstract: McIlroy leapfrogged to the top of the leaderboard with a stunning bunker shot on No. 10 for eagle. He and Hovland were tied heading into the final round on Sunday.

multimedia.caption: Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy, left, and Norway's Viktor Hovland on the 10th hole after McIlroy’s eagle from the bunker.
Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy, left, and Norway's Viktor Hovland on the 10th hole after McIlroy’s eagle from the bunker.
Northern Ireland's Rory McIlroy, left, and Norway's Viktor Hovland on the 10th hole after McIlroy’s eagle from the bunker.

title: Could a Scot Please Win the British Open One Day? Is That Too Much to Ask?
abstract: The last golfer from Scotland to win the British Open was Paul Lawrie in 1999 at Carnoustie, and his victory was somewhat of a fluke.

multimedia.caption: Paul Lawrie, during a celebration of past champions ahead of the 2022 British Open.
Paul Lawrie, during a celebration of past champions ahead of the 2022 British Open.
Paul Lawrie, during a celebration of past champions ahead of the 2022 British Open.

title: Can Galen Rupp outrun the shadow of a disgraced former coach?
abstract: Galen Rupp is the greatest American distance runner of his generation. For a long time, the disgraced coach Alberto Salazar guided him. Should that matter?

multimedia.caption: Galen Rupp set his sights on winning the marathon during the world championships at Hayward Field, on his college campus.
Galen Rupp set his sights on winning the marathon during the world championships at Hayward Field, on his college campus.

title: Golf’s Birthplace Faces a Risky Future on a Warming Planet
abstract: The Old Course, site of this year’s British Open, could be more vulnerable to floodwaters in the coming decades. Other links courses are even more imperiled.

multimedia.caption: A view from the 14th hole at the Old Course at St. Andrews, Scotland.
A view from the 14th hole at the Old Course at St. Andrews, Scotland.

title: Here’s what to watch at the world Championships on Saturday.
abstract: Marcell Jacobs, the Tokyo Olympics gold medalist in the 100 meters, and Sifan Hassan, the Toyko Olympic gold medalist in the 10,000 meters, both return to the global stage.
byline: By Scott Cacciola and Kris Rhim

multimedia.caption: Sifan Hassan won the women’s 10,000 meters at the Tokyo Olympics to pull off an extraordinary feat, winning medals in three grueling events: the 1,500, the 5,000 and the 10,000 meters.

title: Allyson Felix’s victory lap wasn’t about the medal
abstract: Felix won yet another world championship medal, her 19th. “I think I felt all the emotions,” she said of her final competitive race.

multimedia.caption: Allyson Felix now has 11 Olympic medals and 19 world championship medals to her name.

title: Why Is the World’s Biggest Track Meet in a Small College Town in Oregon?
abstract: Eugene, Ore., has spent more than a century evolving into “TrackTown.” On Friday, the World Athletics Championships opened in this unlikely destination.

title: M.L.B. to Pay $185 Million Settlement in Minor League Wage Dispute
abstract: The agreement provides only a modest sum to most players but could speed up the overhaul of how minor leaguers are compensated in the future.

title: At the British Open, It’s the PGA Tour Faithful Against LIV Golf
abstract: “Everybody, it feels like, is against us, and that’s OK,” said Talor Gooch, a LIV golfer tied for eighth at seven under after the second round. Cameron Smith held the lead at 13 under par.

multimedia.caption: Rory McIlroy, tied for third after the second round, has spoken vehemently against the LIV Golf series.
